scenario:
Hexcel, a supplier of composite materials to the aerospace industry, had a poor year in 2024 with its shares trading down 15% despite the S&P 500 being up 23%. The company's troubles are largely due to Boeing's reduced demand for its materials, which makes up nearly two-thirds of Hexcel's revenue. Boeing's manufacturing and engineering issues have led to a government-ordered slowdown in aircraft production, affecting Hexcel's production. 

Hexcel's financial expectations for 2024 were lowered and it withdrew its longer-term guidance for double-digit compound annual revenue growth through 2026. Despite this, the company's management has done a decent job returning capital to investors, with a 4% decrease in share count over the past year and a 16% decrease over the past decade. Hexcel also pays a modest dividend, yielding about 1%. 

The company's composite materials are a must-have part of the new plane supply chain, with Airbus forecasting demand for over 42,000 new deliveries over the next 20 years. However, investors will need to wait for Boeing's slump to recover before seeing Hexcel's business rebound.
